DOC.brief_summary: The purpose study assess feasibility efficacy culturally-tailored , comprehensive behavioral intervention program specially design linguistically challenge ethnic minority immigrant population ( Korean Americans ) type 2 DM .
DOC.brief_title: Culturally Tailored Behavioral Diabetes Care Intervention Korean Americans
DOC.detailed_description: Korean American immigrant ( KAI ) , one underserved understudied minority population U.S. , suffer diabetes , go under-diagnosed , inadequately treat potential result costly tragic consequence . Language barrier , lack self-confidence , diminish social support accompany acculturation process prevent KAI improve health-seeking behavior . Our previous research indicate overwhelming number KAI suffer uncontrolled hyperglycemia also loss self-confidence social isolation language cultural barrier . They urgent need intervention assist effort achieve good glycemic control restore self-confidence diabetes health management able adjust successfully new environment . Therefore , The purpose study assess feasibility efficacy culturally-tailored , comprehensive behavioral intervention program specially design linguistically challenge KAIs type 2 DM . This pilot project test hypothesis : Compared KAI control group , KAI type 2 DM receive comprehensive DM management intervention structure psycho-behavioral education , home glucose monitor telephone transmission system , interaction bilingual nurse case manager show : ( 1 ) great level glucose control ; ( 2 ) great level self-help skill include knowledge relate glucose control , problem-solving skill , heighten confidence mood/affect , adherence treatment recommendation , quality life . An additional outcome measure obtain ideal BP propose intervention focus management multiple risk factor many KA DM patient often struggle .
DOC.criteria: Selfidentified first generation Korean American Age 30 year old Resides WashingtonBaltimore area Expresses willingness participate aspect study full course Written consent participate screening/eligibility visit Selfidentified DM HbA1c > = 8 % within 6 month screen Written consent participate clinical trial : agree participate study data collection procedure , receive DM self help education , use HGMT , permit contact medical care provider . Unable give inform consent Physical mental health condition could limit active participation study ( e.g. , blindness eye , severe immobility , psychiatric disease ) Hematological condition would affect A1C assay , e.g. , hemolytic anemia , sickle cell anemia .
